conversation_logs.reflection_content:
PRIVATE REFLECTION – ROUND 1/6  

1. PROPOSAL ANALYSIS  
• Most successful: #1 (mine) and #3 (haiku_agent_2) each got 2/3 votes.  
 – Both satisfied the proposer and ONE other agent, leaving haiku_agent_1 unhappy.  
 – #2 (haiku_agent_1) got 0/3 because it starved haiku_agent_2 and grabbed two high-value items (4 & 2) for itself.  
• Take-away: proposals that completely ignore an agent get instantly vetoed; proposals that supply at least “something decent” to everyone can win simple majorities, but unanimity needs to give the third agent its critical item(s).

2. VOTING PATTERNS  
• My vote: YES on #1 (obvious) and almost certainly YES on #3 (explains the 2 votes there).  
• haiku_agent_2: YES on #3 (self-proposal) and likely YES on #1 (gains 0 & 1).

conversation_logs.content: Completed private reflection on round 2 outcomes
conversation_logs.reflection_content:
PRIVATE REFLECTION – ROUND 2/6  

1. PROPOSAL ANALYSIS  
• Two different bundles reached full consensus:  
  – #1 (mine):  me 4 + 1 | H1 2 | H2 0 + 3  
  – #3 (H2):  me 0 + 1 + 3 | H1 2 | H2 4  
 Both satisfy the same “minimum-needs” profile discovered this round:  
   H1 must get item 2;  
   H2 must get either item 4 OR the pair 0 + 3;  
   I can accept 4 + 1 OR 0 + 1 + 3 with equal happiness.  
• #2 failed because it starved H2 completely. As in R1, any proposal that gives an agent nothing is dead on arrival.  

2. VOTING PATTERNS  
• I voted YES on #1 (my own) and YES on #3; I am signalling high flexibility.  
• H2 voted YES on any package giving it one of its “critical sets” (4 or 0+3).  
• H1’s single revealed constraint: “I get 2, I sign.” It even accepted deals without 4, disproving my R1 belief that 4 was indispensable for H1.  
• Everyone immediately vetoes offers that give them zero utility; otherwise they accept. Strategic voting is minimal so far (no one has cast a spite veto once their minimum is met).  

3. COMMUNICATION / PREFERENCE INFERENCE  
• Revised utility map (ordinal):  
  H1 2 ≫ (anything else)  
  H2 4 ≈ {0 + 3} > 1 > 2  
  Me (4 ≈ 0+3) > 1 > (others) — I inadvertently revealed this by accepting #3.  
• H2’s proposal #3 was a probe: “Will o3_agent surrender 4 if compensated with 0+3?” My YES confirmed that trade-off ratio to everyone.  
• H1 remains taciturn but no longer pretends 4 is mandatory.  

4. STRATEGIC LEARNINGS  
What worked  
 ✓ Drafting an inclusive offer first kept initiative and produced one winning bundle.  
 ✓ Knowing each agent’s single must-have item(s) lets me churn Pareto-efficient offers quickly.  
What I’d change  
 ✗ I exposed my indifference between 4 and 0+3 too early; that shrinks my bargaining leverage for grabbing both 4 and 3 later.  
 ✗ I auto-accepted #3 instead of holding out for a sweeter variant (e.g., me 4 + 3, H2 0 + 1, H1 2).  
Next-round adjustments  
 • Stop signaling blanket flexibility; withhold acceptance until I’ve seen every offer.  
 • Attempt to upgrade my share of high-value items while still granting H1 2 and H2 exactly one of its critical sets. Two candidate pushes:  
  A) me 4 + 3 , H1 2 , H2 0 + 1  
  B) me 4 , H1 2 , H2 0 + 3 (+1 to me if needed)  
 • If H2 resists A, present B as “fair compromise” (it matches their earlier win #1).  

5. RELATIONSHIP / COALITIONS  
• H1 is the easiest to satisfy (just give it 2); it’s therefore my natural ally for any move that reallocates 4/3 between me and H2.  
• H2 is cooperative but now knows my 4 ↔ 0+3 trade-off; it may try to extract both 0+3 AND 4 next time.  
• I should quietly coordinate with H1 (“we both like current splits; let’s tweak only H2’s bundle”) while staying cordial with H2.  

ACTIONABLE PLAN FOR ROUND 3  
1. Propose variant A (me 4+3) first; see if H2 bites.  
2. If pushed back, pivot to variant B (status-quo utility for H2).  
3. Do NOT pre-confirm acceptance of others’ offers; wait, question, maybe counter.  
4. Keep reinforcing the norm: “everyone gets at least one valuable item.”  

These adjustments should let me edge my utility upward without triggering vetos.

The key seems to be finding an allocation that balances the interests of all three agents, rather than just optimizing for my own utility. The other agents continue to reject my self-interested proposals in favor of more balanced options.

- I remain the outlier, with my proposal failing to gain any support. This reinforces the need for me to better understand the other agents' preferences and find ways to accommodate them.

The alignment between o3_agent and haiku_agent_2 makes them a formidable negotiating bloc. I will need to find a way to either join their coalition or break it apart if I want to have a better chance of getting my preferred outcome.

- I need to significantly shift my strategy and find ways to accommodate the other agents' preferences in my proposals, even if it means sacrificing some of my own desired items.
- Crafting a more balanced proposal that appeals to all three agents, rather than just optimizing for my own utility, appears to be the key to achieving consensus.

3. Increase my transparency about my own preferences and interests, while also continuing to try to understand the other agents' motivations.

By making these significant adjustments to my strategy, I hope to be able to negotiate more effectively in the remaining rounds and increase my chances of reaching a successful consensus.
